feelingNow.value: I'm really scared about what comes next

intro_letter_body.value:
Dear April,

We understand how frightening this moment can feel — the fear of the unknown, the worry about what comes next, or what this means for your health and future. Feeling scared is a natural reaction to receiving news like this.We’ve created this report to help guide you through the information step-by-step, so you can feel more grounded, less overwhelmed, and more confident as you talk with your medical team about your options.

With care and respect,
Your Defiant Health Team
care@defianthealth.com

cancer_type.explanation: Cancer from lobules (milk-producing area of breast) spreading into surrounding breast tissue.
cancer_type.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente9.pdf

location_of_tumors.value: Right breast, 11 o'clock, Right breast, central to nipple, posterior depth
location_of_tumors.explanation: The location of a breast tumor is important to help your medical team assess the likelihood of lymph node involvement and guide surgical treatment.
location_of_tumors.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente3.pdf

size.explanation: The size of the tumor is important in guiding treatment. Different sized tumors may require different approaches. Additionally, knowing the initial size allows doctors to compare images taken after treatment to determine whether the tumor has shrunk or is responding to treatment.
size.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente9.pdf

largest_size_imaging.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente2.pdf

largest_size_biopsy.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente9.pdf

stage.explanation: Tumor larger than 5 cm or multiple lymph nodes affected.
stage.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente9.pdf

stage_type.explanation: A precise assessment of stage done after surgery that includes surgical and microscopic findings for tumor size, lymph node involvement, and metastasis.
stage_type.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente9.pdf

staging_stated_or_inferred.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente9.pdf

overall_grade.explanation: A grade 1 (out of 3) from the Nottingham grading system indicates slow-growing cells that look nearly normal under microscope.
overall_grade.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente9.pdf

er_status.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente3.pdf

pr_status.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente3.pdf

erpr_status.explanation: Cancers that are estrogen (ER) or progesterone (PR) positive are commonly referred to as hormone-receptor (HR) positive. For cancers similar to yours that are HR-positive, endocrine therapy (hormone-blocking treatments) is often used as a treatment option for slowing or stopping cancer growth in cancers like yours.
erpr_status.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente3.pdf

hormone_receptor_status.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente3.pdf

her2_status.explanation: HER2-negative breast cancer is a type of breast cancer where the cancer cells have no levels of the HER2 protein (human epidermal growth factor receptor 2) on the surface of the cell. Cancers that are not HER2 positive tend to be less aggressive and are not treated with HER2 targeted therapy.
her2_status.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente3.pdf

tests.explanation: A routine X-ray exam of the breasts used to check for signs of cancer in women who have no symptoms.
tests.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente.pdf

tests.explanation: A more detailed X-ray of the breast used to investigate suspicious changes found on a screening mammogram.
tests.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente2.pdf

tests.explanation: This test uses sound waves to create pictures of the inside of the breast. It helps distinguish between fluid-filled cysts and solid masses and gives more detail about an area seen on a mammogram or felt on exam.
An axillary ultrasound looks at the lymph nodes under the arm using sound waves. It helps check whether any lymph nodes appear enlarged or suspicious, which can guide whether a biopsy is needed.
A breast MRI uses magnets—not radiation—to take very detailed pictures of the breast. It is often used to look more closely at the extent of cancer, evaluate dense breast tissue, or plan surgery.

tests.test_name: CT scan of chest, abdomen, pelvis and Bone scan
tests.patient_facing_label: CT scan of chest, abdomen, pelvis and Bone scan
tests.explanation: A CT scan uses X-rays to create detailed pictures of the inside of the body, and a bone scan uses a small amount of tracer to look for changes in the bones. Together, they help detect whether breast cancer has spread beyond the breast and lymph nodes.

A PET/CT combines a CT scan’s images with the PET scan’s ability to find active cancer cells using a small amount of radioactive sugar. It helps doctors look for cancer that may have spread to other parts of the body and evaluate how the cancer is behaving.

An echocardiogram uses sound waves to show how the heart is pumping. It is often done before certain breast cancer treatments—especially some chemotherapies or HER2-targeted therapies—to make sure the heart is healthy.
A test to see if the breast cancer cells have receptors for the hormone estrogen, which can help guide treatment.
tests.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente3.pdf

tests.explanation: A test to see if the breast cancer cells have receptors for the hormone progesterone, which can help guide treatment.
tests.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente3.pdf

tests.explanation: A test to look for the HER2 protein, which can promote the growth of cancer cells.
tests.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente3.pdf

tests.explanation: This test checks whether the tumor expresses PD-L1, a protein that can make cancer cells harder for the immune system to recognize. It helps determine whether immunotherapy may be an effective part of treatment.
A genomic test that analyzes the activity of a group of genes in breast cancer tissue to help predict the risk of recurrence and benefit from chemotherapy.
tests.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente8.pdf

tests.test_name: NGS (Next generation sequencing) or liquid biopsy (ctDNA)
tests.patient_facing_label: NGS (Next generation sequencing) or liquid biopsy (ctDNA)
tests.explanation: NGS tests the tumor’s DNA (from tissue or a blood sample) to identify specific genetic changes in the cancer. It helps determine if targeted treatments might work and can uncover mutations that influence treatment planning.

tests.test_name: Germline genetic testing including breast cancer mutations
tests.explanation: A test to check for inherited gene mutations that may increase the risk of developing cancer.

tests.test_name: Blood test: CBC, CMP, TSH, Hep B
tests.patient_facing_label: Blood test: CBC, CMP, TSH, Hep B
tests.explanation: These routine blood tests check blood counts, liver and kidney function, thyroid levels, and prior exposure to hepatitis B. They help ensure treatments can be given safely and identify any issues that need to be addressed before starting therapy.

These are tumor marker blood tests that measure proteins sometimes released by breast cancer cells. They aren’t used to diagnose cancer, but in some cases they can help track the cancer over time or monitor response to treatment.

tests.test_name: List other tests completed not otherwise covered in this list above
tests.explanation: A procedure that uses a special mammography machine to guide a needle to a specific area of the breast to remove a tissue sample.
tests.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente4.pdf

tests.test_name: List other tests completed not otherwise covered in this list above
tests.explanation: A laboratory analysis of the tissue removed during the biopsy to diagnosis the specific type of breast cancer.
tests.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente3.pdf

tests.test_name: List other tests completed not otherwise covered in this list above
tests.explanation: An injection of a radioactive tracer to help identify the sentinel lymph node(s) during surgery.
tests.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente6.pdf

tests.test_name: List other tests completed not otherwise covered in this list above
tests.explanation: A laboratory analysis of the tissue removed during the mastectomy to confirm the diagnosis and check surgical margins.
tests.source: Test Results _ Medical Record _ Kaiser Permanente9.pdf

tests.explanation: Fertility specialists help you understand how breast cancer treatments—like chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, or surgery—may affect future fertility. You may meet with a reproductive endocrinologist, fertility nurse, or reproductive counselor. Their focus is to explain options such as egg or embryo freezing and help you make decisions that match your personal goals before treatment begins.

Genetic counselors are trained professionals who explain whether your cancer might be linked to an inherited genetic change, such as BRCA1 or BRCA2. You might see a certified genetic counselor, a genetics nurse, or a medical geneticist. Their role is to help you understand testing options, what your results mean for treatment choices, and how they may affect family members.
A referral to a doctor who specializes in treating cancer with medication, such as chemotherapy or hormone therapy.
A meeting with a surgeon specializing in breast cancer to discuss surgical treatment options.
A meeting with a plastic surgeon to discuss options for breast reconstruction.

tests.patient_facing_label: Pre-operative Consultation with Breast Surgeon (Dr. Patel)
tests.explanation: A meeting with the surgeon to plan and prepare for the upcoming breast surgery.
A follow-up appointment to check healing and recovery after breast reconstruction surgery.

Radiation oncologists are doctors who design and deliver radiation therapy to treat breast cancer. You may be referred to a radiation oncologist along with radiation therapists and specialized nurses who help guide the process. They focus on targeting radiation precisely to the breast or nearby lymph nodes to reduce the risk of cancer returning after surgery.

diagnosis.title: Hormone Receptor & HER2 Status
diagnosis.body: You may hear a lot about Hormone Receptor Status & HER2 Status when it comes to your cancer care, as these are key inputs in determining your treatment plan. We highlighted a few options above, but will dive into greater detail down below.

diagnosis.title: Goals of Treatment
diagnosis.body: Treatment goals can differ depending on your diagnosis (and your own personal goals). For Stage IIB breast cancer, the goals are to remove the tumor(s), evaluate nearby lymph nodes, and reduce the risk of the cancer returning.

diagnosis.title: Your Care Team
diagnosis.body: Finding the right oncology team is key — you want to make sure they feel right for you. You want doctors who listen, have the expertise, and treat you as a partner. Below, we'll introduce the types of providers you can expect to work with.

testing_and_consultations.title: Currently in: Treatment
testing_and_consultations.body: Even if you are already in treatment, your care team may still want additional testing in order to continue to personalize your care, monitor your health, and guide any future treatments.

testing_and_consultations.title: Identify Your Support Needs
testing_and_consultations.body: Consider what help you might need during treatment — childcare, meals, rides, etc. If there are needs you identify that you don't have support for, your care team can help connect you with resources.

testing_and_consultations.title: Additional Testing
testing_and_consultations.body: These tests and consultations highlighted above can help continued to refine your specific diagnosis to better tailor your treatment — work with your care team to determine what's right for you.

treatment_planning.title: Endocrine Therapy is Highly Likely
treatment_planning.body: Because your cancer is hormone receptor positive (responds to estrogen), endocrine therapy can be one of the most effective treatments available for cancers like yours.

treatment_planning.title: Surgery is Likely Your First Step
treatment_planning.body: For early-stage breast cancer like yours, removing the tumor through lumpectomy or mastectomy is typically the first treatment to eliminate the cancer from your body.

treatment_planning.title: Your Input Matters
treatment_planning.body: While your doctors recommend what's medically best, your goals should be part of the conversation. Write down your questions, and see our Visit Prep guide for key questions to ask, personalized to you.
